Madhur Anand
Feb 2

Short story: What does art feed?

Reading time: 12 minutes

7.00 am.

Tathya walked out of his hut and into the morning fog.

Should I go running, practice flute or help others with the farm work? If I run for 20 mins, I could then practice flute for an hour and then later I could join everyone in the farm work. But it was just too cold to go running. And I am just too cold to have proper blow for flute. And if I let go of music or running practice, I will soon become lazy and my practice would falter. I would go back to being a bum. The others in the commune might be waiting for me to help out. Maybe they think of me as someone who doesn’t contribute enough physically. I wouldn’t like to be thought in that way.

All these thoughts rummaged around his head and he felt his willpower struggling to decide. He had to choose at least something to do. He had gotten out of the bed 20 minutes ago and he was still wondering what to do. He felt mad at himself for being so indecisive. Then he realised he hasn’t brushed his teeth yet. He decided to start with that.

The morning tea was ready. After brushing his teeth with the Neem brush, he sat down with a glass of tea. He picked a book by Proust and hoped for some inspiration from the lexical time-travelling sentences of the writer.

Tathya’s short stories had become popular last year. They impressed teens and adults alike. He had a deal for writing a novel. He dreaded the offer and found himself incapable of the endeavour. His popularity escalated, from being an obscure writer with obscure blog title that only a friend read, which he made it sound fancy by telling that friend to not tell anyone about the blog as it was personal and only for eyes of someone close, to being featured on Medium and then being published by a national newspaper.

But then the downfall came. He hadn’t written for months. His inspiration and imagination had been leaking dry and he had written only blank pages in his distracted 10-minute writing sittings. He dreaded writing blank pages. Now he was too scared to create New Document 23 in his writing folder. The pages weren’t completely blank to be precise; they had some words and a few misplaced punctuations.

His travels in past year had enriched him but also made cynical about world. There was just so much destruction happening to people, nature, and culture all around. Every thing was being cut into money. It was like everyone wanted to be Midas. On top of that, love in his life had gone away last year and nothing had returned yet.

He couldn’t really focus on Proust’s sentences today. His glass was empty now and only the gestalt herb-remains stared back at him from the bottom of the glass. His phone screen showed 8 am when fingered out of darkness. He made up his mind to practice flute. He would begin by walking around and listening to the tanpura for first 10 minutes. He put on the earphones and pressed play. The track came to life and droned in. He focused on the higher pitches. Then the lower ones and listened in hard.

He walked into the banana patch in front of the biggest hut in the commune. Last few days had been too cold and the leaves had died of the frost. He hoped that at least the plants were alive. He checked for signs of green. There were none.

An Indori friend had sent these plants. They were cared for last many months.

My attempts at growing plants were not being successful. This land isn’t good enough and maybe I am wasting my time tending to it. I should perhaps get onto something better in life.

A squirrel broke his train of worrisome thoughts. The squirrel lay dead. He bent down and took a close look. No ants had found their way to the food. No signs of injury. Did the cold take away this poor squirrel’s life?

He pitied its fate and got up.

He looked at his phone. 8.20 am. He cringed. Already 20 minutes have been spent and he had just been lost in his thoughts about the plants. He hadn’t paid attention to the tunes from tanpura. He should have sat down by now for the practice. He pulled out the earphones.

Walking back he entered the biggest hut. All the huts were built circular. He spread a mat and took out his flute. He resumed the tanpura. Sitting cross-legged he held the flute into the right posture. Just as he was about to blow, his eyes caught a squirrel. Another one and it sat still. He got up to take a closer look. This one was dead too. Why are the squirrels dying suddenly?

He scooped it and walked out to lay it in open. The jungle cats would relish it. The first one would have been devoured already, he thought. He went to the spot where the first one lay. To his surprise it was still there. He laid down the second one. Sun had already climbed quarter of the sky. He decided to join the others digging the pond and walked back. Music practice will now happen in the evening.

After the lunch, which would usually happen at 1 pm, Tathya settled into his cot for a short afternoon nap. He turned to the side to put his glasses underneath the cot. But before he could take of his glasses something caught his eye. Another dead squirrel. He sat up. Three dead squirrels in a day! He took a closer look. This one had ant like little insects which he had never seen before.

Were these squirrels dying of the cold? Or was it something else? He wondered.

The hut was round, to one side was his cot and to the other his bags. He heard some noise on the other side. He got up to take a look. A squirrel popped out and dashed to the door. It held there and looked back. Thankfully this one was alive. Tathya stared back. The squirrel lost interest and started sniffing around. It found a peanut and started nibbling. Tathya moved closer. Squirrel saw the danger and ran out of the hut. Tathya followed. He was worried about what was happening to squirrels.

The squirrel dashed to the hand-pump in the south and then to the Chironji tree further on. Tathya followed after. It had climbed the tree. He stood underneath looking up. It sat on the branch right above Tathya’s head. It looked down and met his eyes. Neither eyes’ said anything.

Then Tathya heard a voice — “What you want?”

He looked around. No one was there. He looked back up.

“Why you follow me?”

It occurred to him that it was the squirrel speaking.

It squeaked again “Why you follow me?”

His brain did a somersault. First dead squirrels, and now a speaking squirrel! What was happening today! He snapped out of his thoughts. It wasn’t polite to stay silent, he thought.

“I found 3 dead squirrels today.“

“Yes, very sad.“ squirrel replied.

“How can you speak? Where do you live? Do you have a human master?“

The squirrel narrowed its eyes. “I free. No master. I live my community.“

A community of squirrels! “Can you take me there?“

“No.“

“Why?“

“You too big.”

Bummer. Of course, how could he go to a squirrel community? He was 5 feet 2, not the tallest of humans but surely a giant for the squirrels. He wished there was a little room like that of Alice in wonderland with cakes to make you small and big.

Maybe there was one. It wouldn’t hurt to ask the squirrel.

“Don’t you have something to make me smaller?”

“I do.”

“Well that solves the problem then!”

“But I don’t have anything to make you bigger.”

That was a serious problem. Alice had both the cakes. How would he return?

Today was turning stranger by the hour.

What if all this is just a dream? If it is then he doesn’t have to worry about growing back up. If it isn’t, well maybe someone in the squirrel community has some thing to make him grow up.

There were hardly any odds, but Tathya was feeling optimist. Who would want to lose the opportunity to grow smaller and visit the squirrels?

“Make me smaller. I’ll come with you.”

The squirrel dashed up the tree.

“Hey! Come back”

Tathya sat down. Maybe the squirrel had gone to get that something.

The squirrel did return. It held a little greenish yellow fruit, the size of baby lemon.

“Squeeze juice and drink.”

“Alright.”

Tathya squeezed the lemon-alike in his mouth. He never had something with so many tastes. It began like sour an orange, then tasted sweet, then bitter like coffee and finally left an after taste like mint. What a fruit!

As Tathya was imagining and enjoying the taste, the trees around started to grow bigger. So did the grass around and the fruit swelled up to look like a papaya. He could no longer hold it. And yes! He had shrunk down. Now he was exactly the size of the squirrel. And damn! The squirrel was now like a beast with huge tail. It’s eyes bigger than Tathya’s.

“Follow” squeaked the squirrel.

He ran after, they entered a burrow in the ground. It was dark and Tathya kept bumping into the mud walls. But there wasn’t much room to go elsewhere, so he continued running down the hole.

Do squirrels live underground? Tathya wondered.

The path went down, then up, then to the left and started emerging to daylight with an ascent. Tathya was having a hard time catching up the pace of squirrel. He wasn’t used to running up and down mud tunnels. But nothing could have prepared him for the sight that lay at the mouth of the tunnel.

There was daylight but he couldn’t see the sky. It looked more like a deep pit in the ground. There were different kind of ferns, smaller plants, and flowers all around. And there were just too many squirrels. Both three-striped and five-striped. Little shelters were built under the leaves. Mounds of dead ants, seeds and other grains. Food.

“Where are you taking me?”

“The guru”

“You have a guru?”

“She knows much”

A ‘she’ guru? Human world is mostly dominated by ‘he’ gurus.

A little shelter decorated with mustard flowers was built in the corner of the pit. There sat another squirrel. ‘She’ looked young unlike human gurus. Her squirrel coat was shiny grey with the black stripes.

The squirrel gave a hi-fived the guru.

“Guru, this man wants talk.”

Tathya realised he should explain himself.

“Hello Ms. Guru, I found 3 dead squirrels today. Then I found this one, and I became aware of your community. I really wanted to see how you lived.”

“You are welcome Mr. Tathya. This one is mischievous; he is not supposed to bring humans here. We stay away from humans. Your kind can’t be trusted.”

She speaks such proper English!

“Of course. Most of my people are busy making money and destroying everything. So yeah even I have hard time trusting some people.”

“So what do you do Mr. Tathya? That’s the question everyone asks in human community, right?”

“Well I am these days learning to build these mud houses that you must have seen.”

He avoided the writing part of his life.

“Yes. They are very warm and hospitable, many of my friends tell. But what’s your profession?”

“Profession?”

“Isn’t that how its among humans? Everyone I meet is a labourer, engineer, CA, doctor etc. Don’t you do any of that?”

“Umm. I am trying to live without doing that. Although I am a writer. I don’t like tell about that since I haven’t written for months. But yeah that’s also something I do.”

“What does a writer do?”

“I write. I write stories, articles etc. etc. one day I will write a novel.”

“That is something new I have heard about your kind.”

Maybe she can tell about the squirrels.

“Guru, I found 3 squirrels dead today, is it the cold? What’s happening to them?“

“Yes that’s very unfortunate. We don’t know. It seems like a strange disease. Even the ants aren’t eating the dead ones. That is very bad.”

“You actually want the ants to eat them?” Tathya was surprised.

“Yes! Why not! That is the cycle of nature. One is food of other. If the ants aren’t eating them, neither would the dogs or cats or any other wild animals. That s not at all good. The cycle broken can only bring more death.”

“You say it’s a disease, are there any other squirrels that are ill?”

“Many. Didn’t you see them on your way.”

“I didn’t pay attention.”

“Well many are saying that they ate a new sweet thing and they have been feeling ill after that. The dead ones you saw ate a lot of it.”

Sweet thing. All of a sudden, Tathya knew what had gone wrong now. Last week, his mother had put poison out to kill the rats. He didn’t know how it looked like, but it is mixed with something sweet.

“I know what’s’ wrong.”

“What is it?” squeaked the guru

“It’s the poison for rats. The squirrels must have eaten that.”

“Oh! You humans and your killing ideas.”

“I am very sorry. I didn’t think it would affect the squirrels. The rats were being a menace so we placed it for them.”

“We must take the dead squirrels away then. If some bird eats them, it will die too.”

“But isn’t that the cycle of nature?”

“Are you kidding me human? That’s what you understood?”

“Sorry. And I will put that poison right away.”

“But how will you do that with your tiny hands?“

“Oh yeah. That squirrel gave me the trick to become small. How do I become big again?”

“I can do that. But you need to promise me something.”

“You have a way! I will do anything. Tell me.”

“Go back and never come back. And never ever tell anyone about this place.”

Tathya thought over it. It was a reasonable demand.

“I promise to never come back. And I will also never hurt a squirrel.”

Ms. Guru gave him a pinkish red fruit. Again the lemon size.

“When you get out of the burrow, squeeze and drink the juice.”

“Thank You!”

He waved good-bye to Ms. Guru. The other squirrel showed the way to the burrow. He left him on the mouth of the tunnel.

“You will have to go further on your own.”

“I will, thank you.”

Tathya started climbing down the tunnel and walking through the darkness. He felt the fruit in his pocket. It was still there. He thought about the whole day. The squirrels had understanding of how life works. Life feeds on life, the guru had said. He thought if that could also be applied to art. Art feeds the imagination. It feeds the culture. Lastly, art feeds art.

His walk through the burrow was complete. He walked out into the light.

I hope this fruit works.

He squeezed the fruit into his mouth. Half the juice fell out and dripped down his neck. He panicked.

What if I don’t grow back enough?

And slowly the trees around him started shrinking, so did the grass and the flowers, which had grown the size of umbrellas. He looked at his hand. The fruit was now the size of a peanut.

Now he had a story to tell, he thought. A squirrel dashed in front of him and stared back.

“Oh I won’t reveal how to go to your home. Never!” he muttered.

The squirrel was still staring. Finally it squeaked.

“Oh yeah! And firstly, I will remove the poison!”

The squirrel dashed out of sight. And Tathya walked on to keep the poison away.

The End.

Written by: Madhur Anand
